"DITCHING
WHAT'S THAT?
Pilots in World War II affectionately nicknamed the
English Channel the "Ditch," and sometimes had to
make forced landings in it. That's why an emergency
landing anywhere at sea in a land aircratt is known as
"Ditching." Interesting isn't it?
NO WET FEET FOR YOU!
Relaxed in your comfortable
seat, you can be secure in the
knowledge that your Rolls-Royce
powered etprop has every
scientihic sateguard that could
possibly be needed for any emer-
gency. And you should be well
aware that Aloha Airlines' splenâ€¢
did record and carefully trained flight crews all add
up to assurance that you'll land where your ticket
says vow will land- -without getting your teet wet!
THERE'S A PROPER PROCEDURE
But just as International Maritime Regulations
quire passengers on the high seas to be instructed in
life-boat procedure, so you, too, should know about
your Jetprop's emergency equipment in the very
unlikely event that you take part in a Ditching,
To make an unexpected sea landing safely and com-
fortably there are a few simple things you must know
how to do. and when to do them. let's proceed, then.
to some pointers on Ditching Procedure . . . so YOu
can take to the water as serenely as a sea gull.
FIRST THINGS
FIRST
Each member of your Alohaliner
crew has been carefully trained
emergency procedure. The
crewy members will assist vou.
but you'll help, of course by
keeping calm and following their
instructions.
Life vests are fashionable in emergency landings.
Yours is quite handsomely tailored. You'll find one
in the zipper pocket on the back of each seat (pas-
sengers in the front row of seats will find theirs in
a rack under the seat)
"PREPARE FOR DITCHING"
Imagine that your Captain has
decided to prepare for a Ditch-
ing.
He'll give the order "Pre-
pare for Ditching." When you
receive the order. remove any
sharp objects such as pencils
from your coat, take off your
glasses, loosen your collar,
move your tie, and if you're wearing high-heeled
shoes, take them off. Don't take off any other clothes.
(You'll want to look your best when you land
and you'll be warmer in the lite ratt, too
Now take your lite vest out and slip it over vour
head with the narrow straps at the back. Attach the
metal ring on the left narrow strap to the snap in
front, and the ring on the right strap to the other
snap.
The vest is very simple to inflate, but don't inflate it
until you are outside the ditched airplane.
READY?
GET SET!
Next, adjust your seat as far for-
ward as it will go (in an upright
position) and fasten your seat
belt snugly around you. Just be-
fore landing, lean forward as far
as possible and rest your arms on
your knees
KEEP SEATED
. AND CALM
You'll next hear the order, "Stand by for Ditching,"
You're in your seat, of course, and when the plane
makes contact with the water you'll feel two bumps
-the first slight, the second stronger. Until the plane
has completely stopped moving, stay in your seat.
Then unfasten your seat belt. You'll be told when
it's time to leave the plane and step into your life raft.
THAT FASHIONABLE VEST
When you're out of the airplane
you can blow up your lite vest
It's very easy. Just pull the two
cords at the bottom with a sharp
jerk downward, first one and
then the otherthe vest does
not inflate immediately, take the
end of the rubber tube voull
